sn22.46:1.5.pli: yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.46:1.5.eng: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.46:1.12.pli: yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.46:1.12.eng: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.46:2.1.pli: Evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato pubbantānudiṭṭhiyo na honti.
sn22.46:2.1.eng: Seeing truly with right understanding like this, they have no theories about the first beginning.
sn22.46:2.1.comm: The theories of the past and the future are detailed at DN 1 and MN 102.

sn22.46:2.2.eng: Not having theories about the first beginning, they have no theories about the final end.

sn22.46:2.3.pli: Aparantānudiṭṭhīnaṃ asati, thāmaso parāmāso na hoti.
sn22.46:2.3.eng: Not having theories about the final end, they don’t obstinately stick to them.

sn22.46:2.4.eng: Not misapprehending, the mind becomes dispassionate towards form,

sn22.46:2.8.pli: viññāṇasmiṃ cittaṃ virajjati vimuccati anupādāya āsavehi.
sn22.46:2.8.eng: and consciousness; it’s freed from defilements by not grasping.

sn22.46:2.9.pli: Vimuttattā ṭhitaṃ. Ṭhitattā santusitaṃ. Santusitattā na paritassati. Aparitassaṃ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati.
sn22.46:2.9.eng: Being free, it’s stable. Being stable, it’s content. Being content, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.

sn22.46:2.10.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn22.46:2.10.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.47:1.2.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā anekavihitaṃ attānaṃ samanupassamānā samanupassanti, sabbete pañcupādānakkhandhe samanupassanti, etesaṃ vā aññataraṃ.
sn22.47:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, whatever ascetics and brahmins regard various kinds of things as self, all regard the five grasping aggregates, or one of them.

sn22.47:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṃ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto, sappurisānaṃ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto
sn22.47:1.4.eng: It’s when an unlearned ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.

sn22.47:1.5.pli: rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā rūpaṃ, rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
sn22.47:1.5.eng: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

sn22.47:1.9.pli: viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
sn22.47:1.9.eng: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

sn22.47:2.1.pli: Iti ayañceva samanupassanā ‘asmī’ti cassa avigataṃ hoti.
sn22.47:2.1.eng: So they’re not rid of this way of regarding things, and the conceit ‘I am’.
sn22.47:2.1.comm: Read avigataṁ (“not rid”) here and SN 22.89:5.9; cf. AN 6.13:6.2, DN 33:2.2.106, DN 34:1.7.63.

sn22.47:2.2.pli: ‘Asmī’ti kho pana, bhikkhave, avigate pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ avakkanti hoti—
sn22.47:2.2.eng: As long as they’re not rid of the conceit ‘I am’, the five faculties are conceived—
sn22.47:2.2.comm: From here the discourse alludes to dependent origination. The sense faculties are “conceived”, i.e. “take rebirth”, like name and form (SN 12.39:1.4) or consciousness (SN 12.59:1.2) or an embryo (MN 93:18.61).

sn22.47:2.3.eng: the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body.

sn22.47:2.4.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, mano, atthi dhammā, atthi avijjādhātu.
sn22.47:2.4.eng: The mind, ideas, and the element of ignorance are all present.
sn22.47:2.4.comm: The “mind” (mano) in the presence of “ignorance” makes choices that drive the cycle (SN 12.25:10.3). Here mano, as usual, signifies the active volitional dimension of mind, while ignorance is shown to be not self-existent, but part of the complex of mental activity.

sn22.47:2.5.pli: Avijjāsamphassajena, bhikkhave, vedayitena phuṭṭhassa assutavato puthujjanassa ‘asmī’tipissa hoti;
sn22.47:2.5.eng: Struck by feelings born of contact with ignorance, an unlearned ordinary person thinks ‘I am’,
sn22.47:2.5.comm: Through “contact” and “feeling” there arises the “grasping” of views of self.

sn22.47:2.6.comm: See Uddālaka’s, “I am that, I indeed am that” (iyam aham asmīyam aham asmīti, Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.10.1) and “I am” (ahamasmi) at Sāman Veda 594.

sn22.47:2.13.eng: ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient’.

sn22.47:3.1.eng: The five faculties stay right where they are.
sn22.47:3.1.comm: This is the one who ends the cycle.

sn22.47:3.2.pli: Athettha sutavato ariyasāvakassa avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjati.
sn22.47:3.2.eng: But a learned noble disciple gives up ignorance about them and gives rise to knowledge.

sn22.47:3.3.eng: With the fading away of ignorance and the arising of knowledge, they don’t think ‘I am’,

sn22.47:3.11.eng: ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient’.”

sn22.48:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the five aggregates and the five grasping aggregates.
sn22.48:1.2.comm: “Grasping” is so central to the concept of the five aggregates that we rarely find the “bare” aggregates mentioned as here. To head off a misunderstanding, the purpose of this discourse is not to establish that an arahant has aggregates free of grasping, since this is not brought up at all. Rather, it is to clarify the nature of grasping in relation to the aggregates.

sn22.48:1.4.eng: And what are the five aggregates?
sn22.48:1.4.comm: The five aggregates are the five “masses” or “conglomerates” or “categories” consisting of all instance of that type of phenomena. So far as I can tell, it was not a Vedic technical term. However, the Jains know khandha as a clump of more than one atom, namely a “molecule” (Tattvārthasūtra 5.5). It seems that, along with other terms of similar meaning (sakkāya and puggala; see notes to SN 22.22 and SN 22.105), it was vocabulary shared with the Jains, though used in different senses. I have not discovered anywhere where the five are grouped together as such, although in the Suttas people who are not Buddhists seem familiar with them.

sn22.48:1.5.pli: Yaṃ kiñci, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, ayaṃ vuccati rūpakkhandho.
sn22.48:1.5.eng: Any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: this is called the aggregate of form.

sn22.48:1.6.eng: Any kind of feeling at all …

sn22.48:1.7.eng: Any kind of perception at all …

sn22.48:1.8.pli: ye keci saṅkhārā atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikā vā sukhumā vā …pe… ayaṃ vuccati saṅkhārakkhandho.
sn22.48:1.8.eng: Any kind of choices at all …

sn22.48:1.9.pli: Yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, ayaṃ vuccati viññāṇakkhandho.
sn22.48:1.9.eng: Any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: this is called the aggregate of consciousness.

sn22.48:1.10.eng: These are called the five aggregates.

sn22.48:2.1.eng: And what are the five grasping aggregates?
sn22.48:2.1.comm: The five aggregates are not presented as a catch-all category that encompasses all of reality, but rather five types of phenomena that provoke attachment, forming the basis of what we take to be “self”. Desire is what drives the formation of attachment, but it requires all the aggregates to function. Thus the “grasping” aggregates are numbered “five” after the hand that grasps.

sn22.48:2.2.pli: Yaṃ kiñci, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ …pe… yaṃ dūre santike vā sāsavaṃ upādāniyaṃ, ayaṃ vuccati rūpupādānakkhandho.
sn22.48:2.2.eng: Any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near, which is accompanied by defilements and fuels grasping: this is called the grasping aggregate of form.
sn22.48:2.2.comm: The text illustrates the noun “grasping” (upādāna) with the future passive participle “graspable” (upādāniya). I render it “fuels grasping” to capture the secondary sense of “fuel” for the fire (SN 12.52:1.2). This is the aspect of the aggregates that stimulate or provoke desire and attachment. The “grasping” itself is the desire and lust for the aggregates (SN 22.121). But desire only functions as part of a system involving all the aggregates, hence the aggregates are neither identical to nor separate from the grasping (SN 22.82:4.3). Elsewhere we find the past participle “grasped” (upādinna) as that which has been “appropriated” or “taken up” at birth (MN 28:6.4).

sn22.48:2.3.pli: Yā kāci vedanā …pe… yā dūre santike vā sāsavā upādāniyā, ayaṃ vuccati vedanupādānakkhandho.
sn22.48:2.3.eng: Any kind of feeling at all …

sn22.48:2.4.pli: Yā kāci saññā …pe… yā dūre santike vā sāsavā upādāniyā, ayaṃ vuccati saññupādānakkhandho.
sn22.48:2.4.eng: Any kind of perception at all …

sn22.48:2.5.pli: Ye keci saṅkhārā …pe… sāsavā upādāniyā, ayaṃ vuccati saṅkhārupādānakkhandho.
sn22.48:2.5.eng: Any kind of choices at all …

sn22.48:2.6.pli: Yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ …pe… yaṃ dūre santike vā sāsavaṃ upādāniyaṃ, ayaṃ vuccati viññāṇupādānakkhandho.
sn22.48:2.6.eng: Any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near, which is accompanied by defilements and is fuels grasping: this is called the grasping aggregate of consciousness.

sn22.48:2.7.eng: These are called the five grasping aggregates.”

sn22.49:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn22.49:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn22.49:1.3.pli: Atha kho soṇo gahapatiputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe…
sn22.49:1.3.eng: Then the householder Soṇa went up to the Buddha …
sn22.49:1.3.comm: The householder Soṇa appears here, in the next Sutta, and in SN 35.128.

sn22.49:1.4.pli: ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho soṇaṃ gahapatiputtaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

sn22.49:2.1.pli: “Ye hi keci, soṇa, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā aniccena rūpena dukkhena vipariṇāmadhammena ‘seyyohamasmī’ti vā samanupassanti;
sn22.49:2.1.eng: “Soṇa, there are ascetics and brahmins who—based on form, which is impermanent, suffering, and perishable—regard themselves thus: ‘I’m better’,

sn22.49:2.4.eng: What is that but a failure to see truly?

sn22.49:2.5.pli: Aniccāya vedanāya dukkhāya vipariṇāmadhammāya ‘seyyohamasmī’ti vā samanupassanti;

sn22.49:2.10.pli: aniccehi saṅkhārehi dukkhehi vipariṇāmadhammehi ‘seyyohamasmī’ti vā samanupassanti;

sn22.49:2.14.pli: Aniccena viññāṇena dukkhena vipariṇāmadhammena ‘seyyohamasmī’ti vā samanupassanti;
sn22.49:2.14.eng: consciousness, which is impermanent, suffering, and perishable, they regard themselves thus: ‘I’m better’,

sn22.49:2.17.eng: What is that but a failure to see truly?

sn22.49:3.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, soṇa, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā aniccena rūpena dukkhena vipariṇāmadhammena ‘seyyohamasmī’tipi na samanupassanti;
sn22.49:3.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who—based on form, which is impermanent, suffering, and perishable—don’t regard themselves thus: ‘I’m better’,

sn22.49:3.4.eng: What is that but seeing truly?

sn22.49:3.8.pli: aniccena viññāṇena dukkhena vipariṇāmadhammena ‘seyyohamasmī’tipi na samanupassanti;
sn22.49:3.8.eng: consciousness, which is impermanent, suffering, and perishable, they don’t regard themselves thus: ‘I’m better’,

sn22.49:3.11.eng: What is that but seeing truly?

sn22.49:4.4.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.49:4.4.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.49:4.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn22.49:4.6.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn22.49:4.7.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.49:4.15.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.49:4.15.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.49:4.17.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn22.49:4.17.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn22.49:4.18.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.49:5.1.pli: “Tasmātiha, soṇa, yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.49:5.1.eng: “So, Soṇa, you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.49:6.1.eng: You should truly see any kind of feeling …

sn22.49:6.4.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.49:6.4.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.49:7.1.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, soṇa, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasmimpi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati, saññāyapi nibbindati, saṅkhāresupi nibbindati, viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati.
sn22.49:7.1.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.49:7.2.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati. Vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn22.49:7.2.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn22.49:7.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn22.49:7.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.5:1.4.comm: Mendicants are similarly enjoined to develop immersion (samādhi) in order to understand the six senses (SN 35.99, SN 35.160) and the four noble truths (SN 56.1).

sn22.5:1.5.eng: A mendicant who has immersion truly understands.

sn22.5:1.7.pli: Rūpassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca, vedanāya samudayañca atthaṅgamañca, saññāya samudayañca atthaṅgamañca, saṅkhārānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca, viññāṇassa samudayañca atthaṅgamañca.
sn22.5:1.7.eng: The origin and ending of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.5:2.1.pli: Ko ca, bhikkhave, rūpassa samudayo, ko vedanāya samudayo, ko saññāya samudayo, ko saṅkhārānaṃ samudayo, ko viññāṇassa samudayo?
sn22.5:2.1.eng: And what is the origin of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?

sn22.5:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
sn22.5:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging.

sn22.5:3.1.eng: What do they approve, welcome, and keep clinging to?

sn22.5:3.2.eng: They approve, welcome, and keep clinging to form.

sn22.5:3.3.pli: Tassa rūpaṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato uppajjati nandī.
sn22.5:3.3.comm: “Relishing” (nandī) is a synonym of “craving” (taṇhā). Here it serves to show how the five aggregates participate in the process of generating one life after the next as depicted in dependent origination. Normally, craving in dependent origination is stimulated by the six senses.

sn22.5:3.5.eng: Their grasping is a requirement for continued existence.

sn22.5:3.6.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

sn22.5:3.7.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

sn22.5:3.8.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn22.5:4.1.eng: They approve, welcome, and keep clinging to feeling …

sn22.5:4.5.pli: Tassa viññāṇaṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato uppajjati nandī.

sn22.5:4.7.eng: Their grasping is a requirement for continued existence.

sn22.5:4.8.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

sn22.5:4.9.eng: Rebirth is a condition that gives rise to old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

sn22.5:4.10.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn22.5:5.1.eng: This is the origin of form,

sn22.5:6.1.pli: Ko ca, bhikkhave, rūpassa atthaṅgamo, ko vedanāya …
sn22.5:6.1.eng: And what is the ending of form, feeling,

sn22.5:7.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
sn22.5:7.1.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging.

sn22.5:8.1.eng: What don’t they approve, welcome, or keep clinging to?

sn22.5:8.2.eng: They don’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging to form.

sn22.5:8.3.pli: Tassa rūpaṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato yā rūpe nandī sā nirujjhati.
sn22.5:8.3.eng: As a result, relishing of form ceases.

sn22.5:8.4.eng: When that relishing ceases, grasping ceases.

sn22.5:8.5.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. …

sn22.5:8.6.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn22.5:9.1.eng: They don’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging to feeling …

sn22.5:9.2.pli: Tassa vedanaṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato yā vedanāya nandī sā nirujjhati.

sn22.5:10.3.pli: Tassa saṅkhāre anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato yā saṅkhāresu nandī sā nirujjhati.

sn22.5:11.2.pli: Tassa viññāṇaṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato yā viññāṇe nandī sā nirujjhati.
sn22.5:11.2.eng: As a result, relishing of consciousness ceases.

sn22.5:11.3.eng: When that relishing ceases, grasping ceases. …

sn22.5:11.4.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

sn22.5:12.1.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpassa atthaṅgamo, ayaṃ vedanāya atthaṅgamo, ayaṃ saññāya atthaṅgamo, ayaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ atthaṅgamo, ayaṃ viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo”ti.
sn22.5:12.1.eng: This is the ending of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.”

sn22.50:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn22.50:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn22.50:1.3.pli: Atha kho soṇo gahapatiputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho soṇaṃ gahapatiputtaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn22.50:1.3.eng: Then the householder Soṇa went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

sn22.50:2.1.pli: “Ye hi keci, soṇa, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā rūpaṃ nappajānanti, rūpasamudayaṃ nappajānanti, rūpanirodhaṃ nappajānanti, rūpanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti;
sn22.50:2.1.eng: “Soṇa, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t understand form, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn22.50:2.2.pli: vedanaṃ nappajānanti, vedanāsamudayaṃ nappajānanti, vedanānirodhaṃ nappajānanti, vedanānirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti;

sn22.50:2.4.pli: saṅkhāre nappajānanti, saṅkhārasamudayaṃ nappajānanti, saṅkhāranirodhaṃ nappajānanti, saṅkhāranirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti;

sn22.50:2.5.pli: viññāṇaṃ nappajānanti, viññāṇasamudayaṃ nappajānanti, viññāṇanirodhaṃ nappajānanti, viññāṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ nappajānanti.
sn22.50:2.5.eng: consciousness, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn22.50:2.6.pli: Na me te, soṇa, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā, na ca pana te āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vā diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
sn22.50:2.6.eng: I don’t deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

sn22.50:3.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, soṇa, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā rūpaṃ pajānanti, rūpasamudayaṃ pajānanti, rūpanirodhaṃ pajānanti, rūpanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānanti;
sn22.50:3.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who do understand form, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn22.50:3.5.pli: viññāṇaṃ pajānanti, viññāṇasamudayaṃ pajānanti, viññāṇanirodhaṃ pajānanti, viññāṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānanti.
sn22.50:3.5.eng: consciousness, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

sn22.50:3.6.pli: Te ca kho me, soṇa, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu ca brāhmaṇasammatā, te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
sn22.50:3.6.eng: I deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

sn22.51:1.2.pli: “Aniccaññeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhu rūpaṃ aniccanti passati. Sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.
sn22.51:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, form really is impermanent. A mendicant sees that it is impermanent: that’s their right view.

sn22.51:1.4.eng: When relishing ends, greed ends. When greed ends, relishing ends.
sn22.51:1.4.comm: “Relishing” (nandi) and “greed” (or “lust”, rāga) are similar in meaning, but with distinct stresses: “relishing” enjoys the object of desire, while “greed” is inflamed by passion for it.

sn22.51:1.5.eng: When relishing and greed end, the mind is freed, and is said to be well freed.

sn22.51:1.6.pli: Aniccaññeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vedanaṃ aniccanti passati. Sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.

sn22.51:1.10.pli: Aniccaññeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saññaṃ aniccanti passati …pe…

sn22.51:1.11.pli: anicceyeva bhikkhave, bhikkhu saṅkhāre aniccāti passati. Sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.

sn22.51:1.15.pli: Aniccaññeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhu viññāṇaṃ aniccanti passati. Sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhi.
sn22.51:1.15.eng: Consciousness really is impermanent. A mendicant sees that it is impermanent: that’s their right view.

sn22.51:1.17.eng: When relishing ends, greed ends. When greed ends, relishing ends.

sn22.51:1.18.eng: When relishing and greed end, the mind is freed, and is said to be well freed.”

sn22.52:1.2.pli: “Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, yoniso manasi karotha, rūpāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassatha.
sn22.52:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, rationally apply the mind to form. Truly see the impermanence of form.

sn22.52:1.3.pli: Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yoniso manasi karonto, rūpāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassanto rūpasmiṃ nibbindati.
sn22.52:1.3.eng: When a mendicant does this, they grow disillusioned with form.

sn22.52:1.4.eng: When relishing ends, greed ends. When greed ends, relishing ends.

sn22.52:1.5.eng: When relishing and greed end, the mind is freed, and is said to be well freed.

sn22.52:1.6.pli: Vedanaṃ, bhikkhave, yoniso manasi karotha, vedanāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassatha.
sn22.52:1.6.eng: Rationally apply the mind to feeling …

sn22.52:1.7.pli: Vedanaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yoniso manasi karonto, vedanāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassanto vedanāya nibbindati.

sn22.52:1.11.pli: saṅkhāre, bhikkhave, yoniso manasi karotha, saṅkhārāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassatha.

sn22.52:1.12.pli: Saṅkhāre, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yoniso manasi karonto, saṅkhārāniccataṃ yathābhūtaṃ samanupassanto saṅkhāresu nibbindati.

sn22.52:1.15.pli: Viññāṇaṃ, bhikkhave, yoniso manasi karotha, viññāṇāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassatha.
sn22.52:1.15.eng: consciousness. Truly see the impermanence of consciousness.

sn22.52:1.16.pli: Viññāṇaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yoniso manasi karonto, viññāṇāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassanto viññāṇasmiṃ nibbindati.
sn22.52:1.16.eng: When a mendicant does this, they grow disillusioned with consciousness.

sn22.52:1.17.eng: When relishing ends, greed ends. When greed ends, relishing ends.

sn22.52:1.18.eng: When relishing and greed end, the mind is freed, and is said to be well freed.”
